{{update|date=July 2018}} {{Politics of Ethiopia}} {{weasel words|date=October 2017}} According to the [[U.S. Department of State]]'s human rights report for 2004 and similar sources, the '''Ethiopian government's human rights''' "remained poor; although there were improvements, serious problems remained".{{update after|2014|8|25}} The report listed numerous cases where police and security forces are said to have harassed, illegally detained, tortured, and/or killed individuals, who were members of opposition groups or accused of being insurgents. Thousands of suspects remained in detention without charge, and lengthy pretrial detention continued to be a problem. Prison conditions were poor. The government often ignores citizens' privacy rights and laws regarding search warrants. [[Freedom House]] agrees; the site gave Ethiopia a six out of seven, which means that it is not free. Although fewer journalists have been arrested, detained, or punished in 2004 than in previous years, the government nevertheless continues to restrict [[freedom of the press]]. The government limits [[freedom of assembly]], particularly for members of opposition groups, and security forces have used excessive force to break up demonstrations. Violence and discrimination against women continue to be problems. [[Female genital cutting|Female genital mutilation]] is widespread, although efforts to curb the practice have had some effect. The economic and sexual exploitation of children continues, as does [[human trafficking]]. [[Forced labor]], particularly among children, is a persistent problem. Low-level government interference with [[Trade unions in Ethiopia|labor union]]s continues. Although the government generally respected the [[free exercise of religion]], local authorities at times interfere with religious practice.<ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41603.htm 2004 County Reports on Human Rights Practices: Africa: Ethiopia], [[US State Department]], Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor, published 28 February 2005 (accessed 8 July 2009)</ref> In order to improve Ethiopia's image, they hired US agencies to improve Ethiopia's image for $2.5 million.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/how-a-us-agency-cleaned-up-rwandas-genocide-stained-image/article2322005/page2/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | title=How a U.S. agency cleaned up Rwanda's genocide-stained image | date=6 September 2012}}</ref> According to report of [[Amnesty International|amnesty international]] 2016/2017 prolonged protests over political, economic, social and cultural grievances were met with excessive and lethal force by police. The report added that the crackdown on the political opposition saw mass [[arbitrary arrest]]s, [[torture]] and other ill-treatment, unfair trials and violations of the rights to [[freedom of expression]] and association. On October 9th 2016, the [[Government of Ethiopia|government]] announced a [[state of emergency]], which led to further [[human rights violations]].<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/countries/africa/ethiopia/report-ethiopia/ ETHIOPIA 2016/2017]</ref> In September 2018, more than 20 have died in ethnic based attacks. Protestors outside the capital have been calling for the prime minister to issue a state of emergency to prevent further killings. == Anti-Terrorism Proclamation == Ethiopia’s Anti-Terrorism Proclamation was introduced in 2009.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/afr25/009/2011/en/ Freedom of Expression and Access to Information in Africa: Ethiopia] AI 27 October 2011</ref> The broad provisions of the Anti-Terrorism Proclamation allow the authorities to criminalize the exercise of [[freedom of expression]].<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/ethiopia-swedish-journalists-must-be-released-immediately-and-unconditional Ethiopia: Swedish journalists must be released immediately and unconditionally] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307154631/http://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/ethiopia-swedish-journalists-must-be-released-immediately-and-unconditional |date=7 March 2012 }} Amnesty International 21 December 2011</ref> Amnesty International believes that at least 108 journalists and opposition members were arrested in 2011 primarily because of their legitimate and peaceful criticism of the government. The sheer numbers involved in this wave of arrests represents the most far-reaching crackdown on freedom of expression seen in many years in Ethiopia.<ref name=pdf2011>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/afr25/011/2011/en/ Dismantling Dissent: Intensified crackdown on free speech in Ethiopia] 16 December 2011</ref>
From March 2011 to December 2011 at least 108 opposition party members and six journalists were arrested in Ethiopia for alleged involvement with various proscribed terrorist groups. The detainees had been charged with crimes under the Anti-Terrorism Proclamation and the Criminal Code. Many arrests in 2011 came in the days immediately after individuals publicly criticized the government, were involved in public calls for reform, applied for permission to hold demonstrations, or attempted to conduct investigative journalism in a region of Ethiopia to which the government severely restricts access.<ref name="pdf2011"/>
Amnesty International believes the individuals will not receive a fair trial and will be convicted for exercising their right to freedom of expression. Many of the detainees complained that they experienced torture and were forced to sign confessions or incriminating evidence. Almost all were denied access to lawyers and family at start of detention.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/afr25/012/2011/en/ Amnesty International report on growing repression in Ethiopia] [[Amnesty International]] 15 December 2011</ref>
The trials have become deeply politicized owing to the interest of senior government officials including the Prime Minister who declared in the national parliament that all the defendants are guilty. The Prime Minister has publicly threatened to carry out further arrests. In the first week of December 135 people were reported to be arrested in [[Oromia]]. Amnesty International calls on the [[United Nations]], [[European Union]], [[African Union]], and governments to: Conduct systematic monitoring of the ongoing terrorism trials and the trials of members of the [[Oromo people]] political opposition arrested during 2011 and make findings public.<ref name="pdf2011"/>
== Political freedom == Two journalists and four opposition politicians of the [[Unity for Democracy and Justice]] (UDJ) party, and the Ethiopian National Democratic party, were arrested on 14 September and on 9 September 2011. They were accused of involvement with the [[Ginbot 7]] group, a banned political party.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/afr25/008/2011/en/ Amnesty action letter Ethiopia] 19 September 2011</ref>
=== Elections === According to [[Amnesty International]] citizens were pressed to leave opposition parties in [[Ethiopian general election, 2010|May 2010 elections]]. Voters in [[Addis Ababa]] were reportedly threatened with the withdrawal of state assistance if they did not vote for the [[EPRDF]]. There was political violence: One candidate and several activists were killed. Registration as candidates was reportedly prevented by armed forces. Opposition parties said that their members were harassed, beaten and detained by the EPRDF in the build-up to the elections. Hundreds of people were allegedly arrested arbitrarily in the [[Oromia region]], often on the grounds of supporting the [[Oromo Liberation Front]] (OLF), an armed group. Detention without trial, torture and killings of Oromos were reported.<ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/en/region/ethiopia/report-2011 Amnesty International's 2011 Annual Report on Ethiopia]</ref>
The Ethiopian People’s Revolutionary Democratic Front ([[EPRDF]]) consolidated political control with 99.6 percent victory in the May 2010 parliamentary elections. According to [[Human Rights Watch]] the polls were preceded by months of intimidation of opposition party supporters. According to European election observers the election fell short of international standards. The government had a five-year strategy to systematically close down space for political dissent and independent criticism.<ref>[[Human Rights Watch]] [https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/wr2011.pdf World Report 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414140057/http://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/wr2011.pdf |date=14 April 2015 }} page 121</ref>
== Freedom of the press == The [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] Article 19 of the [[Freedom of speech|freedom of expression]] states: ''Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.''
According to [[Reporters Without Borders]] Ethiopia was 139 out of 178 in its latest worldwide index in January 2012.<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/report-ethiopia,16.html Ethiopia [[Reporters Without Borders]]] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204195134/http://en.rsf.org/report-ethiopia%2C16.html |date=4 December 2011 }} January 2012</ref><ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ethiopia.html Ethiopia articles Reporters Without Borders]</ref>
Government censorship, harassment and arrest of bloggers and journalists severely restricts freedom of the press in Ethiopia: * in December 2009, Martin Schibbye and Johan Persson were convicted for "rendering support to terrorism" and entering the country illegally "to commit an act that is a threat to the well-being of the people of Ethiopia. Status:Pardoned<ref name=hrwdecimates>{{cite web|title=Ethiopia: Terrorism Law Decimates Media|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/05/03/ethiopia-terrorism-law-decimates-media|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref> * in 2011, Hellman-Hammett Award winner Woubshet Taye Abebe was arrested. He was charged under the anti-terrorism law. Before his arrest, he was the deputy editor of the ''Awramba Times''. Status: In prison<ref name=hrwdecimates /> * in 2012, Reeyot Alemu Gobebo, a journalist for Feteh, was convicted on three counts under the terrorism law and initially sentenced to 14 years in prison. This sentence was reduced to 5 years on appeal. Status: In prison.<ref name=hrwdecimates /> * in 2012 [[PEN/Barbara Goldsmith Freedom to Write Award]] recipient [[Eskinder Nega]] was arrested under terrorism charges for his reporting on the [[Arab Spring]];<ref>{{cite news| title= Eskinder Nega, Ethiopia. Status: In Prison|url=http://www.pen.org/defending-writers/eskinder-nega|accessdate=31 July 2014 |publisher=PEN America}}</ref> * in 2014 six members of the [[Zone 9 bloggers|Zone 9 blogging collective]] were arrested under terrorism charges related to their reporting and use of online encryption tools.<ref>{{cite news| title= Contextual Translation of the Charges of the Zone9 Bloggers|url=http://trialtrackerblog.org/2014/07/19/contextual-translation-of-the-charges-of-the-zone9-bloggers/|accessdate=31 July 2014 |publisher=Trial Tracker |date=19 July 2014 }}</ref>
All of the above individuals were held at the [[Kaliti Prison]].
== Freedom of association ==
The Charities and Societies Proclamation No. 621/2009 of Ethiopia (Civil Society Law or CSO law) was enacted on January 6, 2009. It claims to ensure "the realization of citizens’ rights to association enshrined in the constitution… as well as …to aid and facilitate the role of [[civil society]] in the overall development of the Ethiopian people", yet many feel this law has been used for the repression of Ethiopian citizens and has been an obstacle to development.{{citation needed |date=August 2014}}{{POV statement |date=August 2014}}
According to a paper by the Center for International Human Rights at Northwestern University School of Law, "The CSO law is the product of the Ethiopian government’s deep suspicion of civil society" and has been frequently used to silence any organization that advocates for human rights in Ethiopia.<ref name=":0">[http://www.law.northwestern.edu/legalclinic/humanrights/documents/EthiopiaCSOPaper-Nov2009.pdf "Sounding the Horn: Ethiopia's Civil Society Law Threatens Human Rights Defenders"], Yalemzewd Bekele Mulat, Cherice Hopkins, and Liane Ngin Noble, Sandra Babcock and Nicolas Martinez (eds.), Center for International Human Rights, Northwestern University School of Law, November 2009.</ref> This law is more draconian than a similar Russian law and is most similar to a draft of a Zimbabwean NGO bill that was never signed into law. Research indicates that Ethiopia’s CSO law is among the most restrictive in the world.<ref name=":0" />
This law prohibits "foreign" NGO’s from engaging in a very wide range of activities including human rights, women’s rights, children’s rights, disability rights, citizenship rights, conflict resolution or democratic governance. The definition of "foreign" NGO was broadened to include local NGOs that receive more than ten percent of their funding from foreign sources. Given that most local NGO’s cannot sustain themselves without some foreign funding, this definition is broad enough to include almost all NGO’s in Ethiopia. However, the government of Ethiopia itself receives 50 to 60 percent of its national budget from foreign governments, which according to its own definition would clearly make it a foreign entity as well.<ref>[http://www.oaklandinstitute.org/development-aid-ethiopia "Development Aid to Ethiopia: Overlooking Violence, Marginalization, and Political Repression "], Oakland Institute, 17 July 2013.</ref>
Over the years Ethiopian organizations that have found themselves to be targets of harassment using the CSO Law include the Ethiopian Human Rights Council (EHRCO), the Ethiopian Women Lawyers’ Association (EWLA) which provided pro bono service to Ethiopian women who could not afford a lawyer. Despite the fact that Article 31 of the Ethiopian Constitution provides that "every person has the right to freedom of association for any cause or purpose", the prohibition of NGO’s by the CSO Law has had the effect of severely restricting citizens’ right of association, as members of NGO’s can not associate freely. {{citation needed |date=August 2014}}
== Electronic communications == {{main article|Internet in Ethiopia}}
In 2012, Ethiopia passed a law that criminalizes providing Internet voice communication ([[Voice over IP|VoIP]]) and requiring inspection of any imported voice communications equipment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.africareview.com/Business---Finance/New-Ethiopian-law-criminalises-Skype/-/979184/1426020/-/u7t2ld/-/index.html|title=New Ethiopian law criminalises Skype, installs Internet filters|publisher=[[Nation Media Group|Africa Review]]|date=12 June 2012|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref> Additionally, it prohibits "bypasses the telecom infrastructure established by the telecom service provider", which restricts Internet access to only the [[Ethiopian Telecommunications Corporation|ETC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chilot.me/2012/12/13/proclamation-no-7612012-telecom-fraud-offence-proclamation/|title=Proclamation No. 761/2012 Telecom Fraud Offence Proclamation (English translation)|publisher=Ethiopian Legal Brief|date=13 December 2012|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abyssinialaw.com/uploads/761.pdf|title=Proclamation No. 761/2012 Telecom Fraud Offence Proclamation|publisher=Abyssinia Law|date=4 September 2012|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref>
According to [[Freedom House]]'s Freedom on the Net 2013 report, Ethiopia ranked 56th out of 60 countries on Internet freedom<ref>{{cite web|title=Freedom on the Net 2013|url=http://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/resources/FOTN%202013_Full%20Report_0.pdf|publisher=[[Freedom House]]|accessdate=24 August 2014|page=25|date=3 October 2013}}</ref> and 47th out of 53 in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freedom on the Net 2012|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/resources/FOTN%202012%20-%20Full%20Report_0.pdf|publisher=[[Freedom House]]|accessdate=24 August 2014|page=26|date=24 September 2012}}</ref>
In October, 2016 many Ethiopians protested against the Government after they prohibit use of social media, and banning several television channels.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37679165|title=Seven things banned under Ethiopia's state of emergency|date=2016-10-17|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> As a result, hundreds of people killed and hundreds more imprisoned.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ecnmy.org/engage/ethiopia-state-emergency/|title=Ethiopia is in a state of emergency. Here's what's going on|newspaper=Economy|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
== Sexual violence == According to surveys in 2003 by the National Committee on Traditional Practices in Ethiopia, [[marriage by abduction]] accounts for 69% of the nation's marriages, with around 80% in the largest region, Oromiya, and as high as 92 percent in the [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/IndepthMain.aspx?InDepthID=28&ReportID=69993 |title=Youth in Crisis: Coming of age in the 21st century |publisher=[[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] |date=23 February 2007 |accessdate=14 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205144923/http://www.irinnews.org/IndepthMain.aspx?InDepthID=28&ReportID=69993 |archivedate=5 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/ethiopia/ET_real_abduction.pdf|title=UNICEF supports fight to end marriage by abduction in Ethiopia|publisher=[[UNICEF]]|accessdate=14 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817054036/http://www.unicef.org/ethiopia/ET_real_abduction.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
According to the 2005 Ethiopian Demographic Health Survey, more than 74% of women between the ages of 15 and 49 have undergone some form of genital mutilation and cutting with more than 97% in the [[Somali region]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/ethiopia_34881.html|title=Battling an ancient tradition: Female genital mutilation in Ethiopia|publisher=[[UNICEF]]|accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref>
==Murder of "cursed" children== Among certain ethnic groups in Southern Ethiopia, babies and young children deemed "cursed" as [[Mingi]] are usually killed by drowning in rivers, pushing them off cliffs, or leaving them in the bush to starve or be eaten by wild animals.<ref name="mingi-ethiopia">''Is the tide turning against the killing of 'cursed' infants in Ethiopia?'' http://www.cnn.com/2011/11/05/world/africa/mingi-ethiopia/index.html?hpt=hp_c2</ref> The [[Karo people (Ethiopia)|Karo]] officially banned Mingi in July 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/explorers/bios/lale-labuko/|title=Lale Labuko|publisher=nationalgeographic.com|accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>
== Forced relocation == The [[Ethiopian government]] relocated forcibly ca 70,000 [[Indigenous peoples of Africa|indigenous people]] from the [[Gambela Region]] between 2010 and January 2012 to new villages that lack adequate food, farmland, healthcare, and educational facilities. State security forces threatened, assaulted, and arbitrarily arrested villagers who resisted the transfers. From 2008 through January 2011, Ethiopia [[Lease#Land lease|leased]] out at least 3.6 million [[hectare]]s of land, an area the size of the [[Netherlands]]. An additional 2.1 million hectares of land is available through the federal government’s land bank for agricultural investment. In Gambella, 42 percent of the land is marketed for investors.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/node/104348 Ethiopia: Forced Relocations Bring Hunger, Hardship] [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) January 2012</ref>
[[Gambela Region]] has a population of 307,000, mainly indigenous [[Anuak people|Anuak]] and [[Nuer people|Nuer]]. Its richly fertile soil has attracted foreign and domestic investors who have leased large tracts of land at favorable prices.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2012/jan/17/ethiopia-relocation-programme-report Thousands 'forcibly relocated' in Ethiopia, says HRW report] Guardian 16.1.2012</ref>
== Incidents ==
In 2005, the [[Ethiopian police massacres|Ethiopian Police Massacre]] took place. In this, it was claimed that the Ethiopian police massacred almost 200 opposition protesters, who were protesting in response to the May 2005 General Elections. During this, live gunfire from government forces was directed at protesters and bystanders.
According to a report released by [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) in June 2008, the Ethiopian army has committed widespread [[execution]]s, [[torture]] and [[rape]] in [[Ogaden]], as part of a [[counterinsurgency]] campaign.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.hrw.org/node/74305 | title = Ethiopia: Army Commits Executions, Torture, and Rape in Ogaden | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]] | date = 2008-06-12 | accessdate= 2008-06-22 }}</ref> The Ethiopian [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Ethiopia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] responded with a big press release stating that they performed an investigation during August and September of that year, which "found no trace of serious human rights violation let alone war crimes or crimes against humanity" during their response to the [[Abole oil field raid]], but claimed the investigation found "a mass of evidence of further systematic abuses committed by the ONLF."<ref>[http://www.mfa.gov.et/Press_Section/Press_Statement_26_November_2008.htm "Human Rights Watch: Flawed Methodology, Unsubstantiated Allegations"], Ethiopian Ministry of Foreign Affairs website (accessed 17 March 2009)</ref> However, the [[U.S. State Department]]'s annual report on human rights notes that [[Lisan Yohannes]], a "former ruling party insider", led the investigation, an appointment which "opens questions about the independence of the investigation."<ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/af/119001.htm "2008 Human Rights Reports: Ethiopia"], Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor, US State Department (accessed 8 July 2009)</ref>
On 6 January 2009, the Ethiopian [[Federal Parliamentary Assembly|parliament]] passed the "Charities and Societies Proclamation (NGO law)", which "criminalizes most human rights work in the country" according to HRW, who added that "the law is a direct rebuke to governments that assist Ethiopia and that had expressed concerns about the law's restrictions on freedom of association and expression."<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/01/08/ethiopia-new-law-ratchets-repression "Ethiopia: New Law Ratchets up Repression"], Human Rights Watch website (accessed 20 March 2009)</ref>
Following the State of Emergency declared in 2016, there were reports of thousands of deaths of citizens.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2017/af/276999.htm|title=Ethiopia|work=U.S. Department of State|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en-US}}</ref> After protests in Oromo, Amhara, and the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's region, The Ethiopian Human Rights Council reported that there were 669 deaths on aggregate.<ref name=":1" /> According to other NGOs and Oromo region officials, there were hundreds of deaths due to militia groups in the eastern side of Ethiopia.<ref name=":1" />
== Detention Centers == The Detention Centers in Ethiopia have come under scrutiny for the conditions present.<ref name=":1" /> The prisons are overcrowded, for example a prison in Asella has a capacity of 400 people, but there are 3000 people there. The prisoners are beaten and killed, like Ayele Beyene in Kilinto who was beaten by guards and then his wounds were ignored which eventually led to his death.<ref name=":1" /> Once people are placed in the prison system their families have little knowledge of their whereabouts. Detainees can not have visitors some places and there is no database or organization to find the location of prisoners.<ref name=":1" />
In a 2017 HRCO report, the conditions of the Finote Selam Prison in Amhara, the Awash Arba Prison, and Kilinto Prison, were revealed.<ref name=":1" /> In the Finote Selam Prison the reports indicated the detainees were beaten and tortured, and the Amahara and Oromo ethnicities were given worse treatment than other groups. Detainees were also subjected to spend time immersed in latrine pits of human feces. In the Awash Arba Prison, they were overcrowded, unfed, beaten, and forced to do manual labor.<ref name=":1" /> In addition, the detainees spent time outside walking barefoot and sitting in the sun for consecutive days. In Kilinto, the prisoners were forced to give confessions at the threat of physical punishment, while being mistreated.<ref name=":1" />
In 2018, under the new leadership of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, the Ethiopian Government closed Jail Ogaden in the Somali Region of Ethiopia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.africanews.com/2018/09/22/ethiopia-s-somali-region-closes-notorious-jail-ogaden/|title=Ethiopia's Somali region closes notorious 'Jail Ogaden' {{!}} Africanews|last=AfricaNews|work=Africanews|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}}</ref> Jail Ogaden was operated under the former leader of the Somali Region, Abdi Mohamoud Omar, with many of the imprisoned there without charges against them.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/report/2018/07/04/we-are-dead/torture-and-other-human-rights-abuses-jail-ogaden-somali-regional|title=“We are Like the Dead” {{!}} Torture and other Human Rights Abuses in Jail Ogaden, Somali Regional State, Ethiopia|date=2018-07-04|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}}</ref> A Human Rights Watch report indicates that the prisoners were malnourished, beaten, and kept in small confines that promoted rampant disease spread.<ref name=":2" /> The former head of the prison Shamaahiye Sheikh Farah was arrested in September of 2018 for his role in the prison. Shamaahiye's most infamous incident of torture was having a month of hunger, where none of the prisoners were allowed to eat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://unpo.org/article/21125?id=21125|title=UNPO: Ogaden: Former ‘Jail Ogaden’ Prison Commissioner Arrested|website=unpo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>

==International Involvement == Ethiopia's stances on [[International human rights law|international human rights treaties]] are as follows:
{| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="border:none; " !International treaties |- | {{DEFAULTSORT:Human Rights In Ethiopia}} [[Category:Human rights by country|Ethiopia]] [[Category:Politics of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Ethiopian society]] [[Category:Human rights in Ethiopia| ]] |} On April 10th 2018, The United States Congress passed Resolution 128, a bill aimed at encouraging human rights, rule of law, and democracy<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/04/10/us-house-resolution-ethiopia-passes|title=Human Rights Watch|website=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>. A congregation of Ethiopian-Americans expressed concern with consistent human right violations of the Ethiopian government. The interest group of Ethiopian-Americans along with lobbyists got 114 representatives and 33 states to co-sponsor the bill<ref name=":3" />. The bill created provisions for independent examinations into the state of human rights in Ethiopia by the United Nations<ref name=":3" />. The bill is non-binding.

[[Marxism]] | regional1_name = | regional2_type = | regional2_name = | student = | website = }} '''Independentist Students''' ('''EI''', ''Estudantes Independentistas'' in [[Galician language]]) was a [[Galician nationalism|Galician independentist]] and [[Socialism|socialist]] [[students' union|student union]], formed by [[university]] students.{{cite web|url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/hemeroteca/2000/05/11/26881.shtml?idioma=galego|title=Unha manifestación de douscentos estudantes conclúe con varias desfeitas no centro histórico|author=La Voz de Galicia|publisher=Lavozdegalicia.es|accessdate=4 January 2015}} FER was founded in December 1995.{{cite web|url=http://estoutrasnotaspoliticas.blogspot.com.es/2006/12/breve-resenha-do-independentismo.html|title=ESTOUTRAS: Breve resenha do independentismo estudantil|publisher=Estoutrasnotaspoliticas.blogspot.com.es|accessdate=4 January 2015}} In 1996 EI gained several representatives in the [[University of Santiago de Compostela]] Council and in the Faculty Councils.EI won the elections in the history and geography faculty, with 11 seats won. In 1996, the student union grew significantly, although in 1997 and early 1998, the organization stopped growing. Despite their early success in the student elections, EI always focused in the ''struggle in the street''; [[Street protest|demonstrations]] and [[Student strike|strikes]] were the main means of struggle. Between 1998 and 2000, the organization grew again, gaining presence in all the universities of [[Galiza]] and getting seats in the faculty and university councils. Between 1998 and 2000 EI also made a lot of common acts, [[Street protest|demonstrations]] and [[strike action|strikes]] with the [[Comités Abertos de Faculdade]] and the [[Movemento Estudantil Universitario]]. In 2001, the group focused more in unity with other [[Galician nationalism|independentist]] and [[Far-left politics|leftist]] collectives, like the [[Revolutionary Students Federation]] or the [[Galician Antifascist Students Assembly]]. In 2001 EI merged with other [[Galician nationalism|galician independentist]] and [[Anticapitalism|anticapitalist]] student unions to form [[AGIR (student organization)]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/hemeroteca/2000/12/19/341230.shtml?idioma=galego|title=Agrupacións extremistas fichadas pola policía coexisten na Universidade de Vigo|publisher=Lavozdegalicia.es|accessdate=4 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305133259/http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/hemeroteca/2000/12/19/341230.shtml?idioma=galego|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=}} A sector of EI didn't want to merge and split from the organization. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Galician nationalism |state=collapsed}} [[Category:Secessionist organizations in Europe]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Galician nationalist parties]] [[Category:Socialism in Spain]] [[Category:Feminism in Spain]] [[Category:Marxist parties]] {{Galicia-stub}}
