{{flag|South Korea}}}} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul = {{linktext|대한민국|임시|정부}} |hanja = {{linktext|大韓民國|臨時|政府}} |rr = Daehanmin(-)guk Imsijeongbu |mr = Taehanmin'guk Imsijŏngbu| }} {{History of Korea}} {{History of South Korea}} The '''Korean Provisional Government''' ('''KPG'''), formally the '''Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea''' was a partially recognized Korean [[government-in-exile]], based in [[Shanghai]], [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|China]], and later in [[Chongqing|Chungking]], during the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese colonial rule of Korea]]. On April 11, 1919, the provisional constitution was enacted, and the national sovereignty was called "Republic of Korea" and the political system was called "Democratic Republic". Introduced the presidential system and established three separate systems of legislative, administrative and judicial separation, the KPG inherited the territory of the former [[Korean Empire]] and stated that he favored the former imperial court. It actively supported and supported the independence movement under the provisional government, and received economic and military support from the [[Kuomintang]] of China, the [[Soviet Union]] and [[French Third Republic|France]]. After the [[Surrender of Japan]] on August 15, 1945, figures such as [[Kim Gu]] returned. On August 15, 1948, the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea was dissolved. Rhee, who was the first president of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea, became the first [[President of South Korea|President of the Republic of Korea]] in 1948. The [[Constitution of South Korea]], which was amended in 1987, stated that the Korean people inherited the rule of the KPG. == History == The government was formed on April 13, 1919, shortly after the [[March 1st movement]] of the same year during the Imperial Japanese colonial rule of the Korean peninsula.''Sources of Korean Tradition'', vol. 2, ''From the Sixteenth to the Twentieth Centuries'', edited by [[Yŏngho Ch'oe]], [[Peter H. Lee]], and [[William Theodore de Bary|Wm. Theodore de Bary]], Introduction to Asian Civilizations (New York: Columbia University Press, 2000), 336. Key members in its establishment included [[An Changho]] and [[Syngman Rhee]], both of which were leaders of the [[Korean National Association]] at that time. An Changho played an important part in making Shanghai the center of the liberation movement and in getting KPG operations underway. As acting premier, he would help reorganize the government from a parliamentary cabinet system to a presidential system. The government resisted the colonial rule of Korea that lasted from 1910 to 1945. They coordinated the armed resistance against the Japanese imperial army during the 1920s and 1930s, including the [[Battle of Chingshanli]] in October 1920 and the assault on Japanese military leadership in [[Shanghai]]'s [[Hongkou Park]] in April 1932. This struggle culminated in the formation of [[Korean Liberation Army]] in 1940, bringing together many if not all Korean resistance groups in exile. The government duly declared war against the [[Axis powers]] Japan and Germany on December 9, 1941, and the Liberation Army took part in allied action in [[Republic of China (1912–49)|China]] and parts of [[Southeast Asia]]. During [[World War II]], the Korean Liberation Army was preparing an assault against the Imperial Japanese forces in Korea in conjunction with American [[Office of Strategic Services]], but the [[Surrender of Japan|Japanese surrender]] prevented the execution of the plan. The government's goal was achieved with Japanese surrender on September 2, 1945, but they were not approved by other governments as a member of allied nations, who signed peace treaty with Japan in San Francisco. The sites of the Provisional Government in [[Shanghai]] and [[Chongqing]] (Chungking) have been preserved as museums. === Foreign relations === In 1919, when U.S. President [[Woodrow Wilson]] ruled for [[national self-determination]], [[Rhee Syng-man]] promoted the League of Nations mandate in the United States, and [[Kim Kyu-sik]] pushed for independence under the approval of a [[Allies of World War I|victorious country]] in Paris.{{cite web |url=http://encykorea.aks.ac.kr/Contents/Index?contents_id=E0044938 |script-title=ko:이승만 |publisher=[[Academy of Korean Studies]] |work=Encyclopedia of Korean culture |accessdate=March 13, 2014 |language=Korean |trans-title=Rhee Syngman}}[[Carter J. Eckert|Eckert, Carter J.]], Lee, Ki-baik, Lew, Young Ick, Robinson, Michael & Wagner, Edward W. (1990). ''Korea old and new''. Seoul: Ilchokak. The provisional government gained approval from [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|China]] and [[Polish government-in-exile|Poland]] through diplomatic efforts.{{cite book |author=[[Ministry of Patriots and Veterans Affairs (South Korea)|Ministry of Patriots and Veterans Affairs]] ({{lang|ko|국가보훈처}}) |script-title=ko:대한민국임시정부의 법통과 역사적 재조명 |year=1997 |publisher=National Archives of Korea |location=Daejeon |pages=167–169 |language=Korean |trans-title=Legitimacy and Historical Review of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea |url=https://www.archives.go.kr/next/search/showDetailPopup.do?rc_code=1310377&rc_rfile_no=200041016929&rc_ritem_no=000000000001#viewer}} Meanwhile, in 1944, the government received approval from the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite web |url=http://folkency.nfm.go.kr/kr/topic/대한민국임시정부수립기념일/3589 |script-title=ko:대한민국임시정부수립기념일 |publisher=[[National Folk Museum of Korea]] |work=Encyclopedia of Korean folk culture |language=Korean |trans-title=Day to celebrate the establishment of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea}} [[Jo So-ang]], the head of diplomatic department of provisional government, met with the French ambassador in Chongqing and was quoted as saying that [[French government]] would give unofficial and substantively approve the government in April 1945.PRC Documents, F. 1864 / 1394 / 23 However, The government did not gain formal recognition from [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]] and other world powers.[https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1944v05/d1230 The Ambassador in China ( Gauss ) to the Secretary of State No. 2583 Chungking , May 19, 1944.(Received June 2.)][https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1944v05/d1232 The Secretary of State to the Ambassador in China ( Gauss )Washington , June 12, 1944—9 p.m.] ==List of presidents== * [[Syngman Rhee]] (September 11, 1919 - March 21, 1925) - Impeached by the provisional assembly ** [[Yi Dongnyeong]] (June 16, 1924 - December 11, 1924) - Acting ** [[Park Eun-sik]] (December 11, 1924 - March 24, 1925) - Acting * [[Park Eun-sik]] (March 24, 1925 – September 1925) ** [[Yi Yu-pil]] (September 1925)-Acting * [[Yi Sang-ryong]] (September 1925 – January 1926) * [[Yang Gi-tak]] (January 1926 - April 29, 1926) * [[Yi Dongnyeong]] (April 29, 1926 – May 3, 1926) * [[Ahn Chang-ho]] (May 3, 1926 - May 16, 1926) * [[Yi Dong-nyeong]] (May 16, 1926 - July 7, 1926) * [[Hong Jin]] (July 7, 1926 – December 14, 1926) * [[Kim Koo]] (December 14, 1926 – August 1927) * [[Yi Dongnyeong]] (August 1927 – June 24, 1933) * [[Song Byeong-jo]] (June 24, 1933 - October 1933) * [[Yi Dongnyeong]] (October 1933 - March 13, 1940) - Died in office * [[Kim Koo]] (1940 - March 1947) * [[Syngman Rhee]] (March 1947 - August 15, 1948) - Became the first president of [[South Korea]], from July 24, 1948 to April 26, 1960 == Gallery == File:Birthplace of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea.jpg|No. 50, Ruijin No. 2 Road, Huangpu District, Shanghai, the birthplace of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea File:Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea.jpg|Photo for memorial of establishing Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea, 1919. '''Qurultay of the Crimean Tatar People''' is a national congress and the highest representing plenipotentiary body of the Crimean Tatar people. At Qurultay the Crimean Tatar people are represented by delegates elected by [[Crimean Tatars]] and members of their family regardless of their nationality permanently residing on the territory of Ukraine as well as those Crimean Tatars and members of their family who are citizens of Ukraine regardless of their place of residence.
The term of composition credentials of Qurultay is five years.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = Sandi Toksvig in 2009.jpg | image_size = 230px | name = Sandi Toksvig | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100|OBE}} | caption = Sandi Toksvig in 2009 | birth_name = Sandra Birgitte Toksvig | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|5|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | citizenship = [[United Kingdom|British]] (from 2013) | alma_mater = [[Girton College, Cambridge]] | parents = [[Claus Toksvig]]{{cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=xxUQIHdkk0koDBTrSGpSig&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=5 August 2015|work=FreeBMD. Marriage registered Q2 1954 in Surrey, England|publisher=ONS}}
Julie Anne Toksvig (née Brett) | occupation = Comedian, author, radio and television presenter, co-founder of [[Women's Equality Party]] | party = [[Women's Equality Party]] | spouse = {{marriage|Debbie Toksvig|2007}} | children = 3 }} '''Sandra Birgitte Toksvig''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|OBE}} ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|t|ɒ|k|s|v|ɪ|ɡ}}, {{IPA-da|ˌsandi ˈtʌɡsviːˀ}}; born 3 May 1958){{Cite journal|date=2007-12-01|title=Toksvig, Sandra Birgitte, (Sandi), (born 3 May 1958), writer and comedian|url=https://doi.org/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.37818|journal=Who's Who|language=en|publisher=Oxford University Press|doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.37818}} is a [[British people|British]]-[[Danes|Danish]] comedian, writer, actor, presenter and producer on British radio and television, and political activist. On 21 October 2016, Toksvig took over from [[Stephen Fry]] as host of the BBC television quiz show ''[[QI]]''. She was the host of ''[[The News Quiz]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]] from 2006 until June 2015. She also presented the quiz show ''[[1001 Things You Should Know]]'' on [[Channel 4]] television in 2012–13, and began hosting a revived series of the same channel's game show ''[[Fifteen to One]]'' on 5 April 2014. She is joint founder of the [[Women's Equality Party]] (established in March 2015), was installed as [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of the [[University of Portsmouth]] in October 2012, and is the current president of the [[Women of the Year Lunch]]. On 16 March 2017, Toksvig was announced as the new co-presenter of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]'', alongside comedian [[Noel Fielding]].{{cite news | last = Ross | first = Alice | title = Noel Fielding and Sandi Toksvig to host new Great British Bake Off | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 16 March 2017 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/mar/16/noel-fielding-and-sandi-toksvig-to-host-new-great-british-bake-off}} ==Early life== Toksvig was born in Denmark. Her father, [[Claus Toksvig]], was a Danish journalist, broadcaster, and foreign correspondent, so Toksvig spent most of her youth outside Denmark, mostly in New York City. Her mother, Julie Anne Toksvig (''[[née]]'' Brett), is British.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13127990.Sandi_Toksvig_minds_her_manners/|first=Rebecca|last=McQuillan|title=Sandi Toksvig minds her manners |work = The Herald Scotland |date=18 October 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2016}} She attended [[Tormead School]], an independent girls' school near [[Guildford]], when her father was based in London. Her first job was a position as a [[follow spot]] operator for the musical ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'' at the age of 18.{{cite book|last=Toksvig|first=Sandi|date=24 January 2013|title=The Chain Of Curiosity |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=guobYpUxBj8C&pg=PT113&lpg=PT113&dq=sandi+toksvig+jesus+christ+superstar&source=bl&ots=R6ZFFDWvvG&sig=l1aiuxxTn6QYrJabmmYYh9pqnio&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-4haU7SgG6Gv7AaYzIDAAQ&ved=0CGMQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=sandi%20toksvig%20jesus%20christ%20superstar&f=false|location=London, UK|publisher=[[Hachette (publisher)|Hachette UK]]|isbn=9781405527231|accessdate=25 April 2014}}{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/3670221/Sandi-Toksvig-All-the-worlds-backstage.html|title=Sandi Toksvig: All the world's backstage|last1=Tokvsig |first1=Sandi |date=30 December 2007 |work= [[The Sunday Telegraph]] |accessdate=25 April 2014}} She read law, archaeology and anthropology at [[Girton College, Cambridge]], graduating with a [[first-class degree]] and receiving two prizes for outstanding achievement (The Raemakers and the Theresa Montefiore Awards).{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2012/jan/23/sandi-toksvig-chancellor-portsmouth-university|title=Sandi Toksvig becomes chancellor of Portsmouth University|last=Press Association|date=23 January 2012|work=The Guardian|accessdate=31 December 2013}} One of her law supervisors was [[Lord Denning]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/qi/episodes/9/8/|title=QI – Series I – Inequality – British Comedy Guide|publisher=comedy.co.uk|accessdate=13 April 2015}} ==Career== {{Quote box |quote=When I see comedian—and ‘comedienne’, of course I hate it—I think ‘Oh, really?’ because I think of myself as a writer and broadcaster. Sometimes it's funny but I’ve just done a piece for [[BBC Radio 3|Radio 3]] all about [[Mary Wollstonecraft]], and there's not a joke in it. |source=''[[The Times]]''|width=25em |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |quoted=true |salign=center}} [[File:Toksvig 2008.jpg|thumb|right|Toksvig performing in 2008]] ===Beginnings=== Toksvig began her comedy career at Girton College, [[Cambridge University]], where she wrote and performed in the first all-woman show at the [[Footlights]]. She was there at the same time as fellow members [[Stephen Fry]], [[Hugh Laurie]], [[Tony Slattery]], and [[Emma Thompson]], and wrote additional material for the [[Perrier award]]-winning [[Cambridge Footlights Revue|Footlights Revue]]. She was also a member of the university's [[Cambridge University Light Entertainment Society|Light Entertainment Society]]. She started her television career on [[children's television|children's series]], presenting ''[[No. 73]]'' (1982–1986), the ''Sandwich Quiz'',{{cite web |url=http://www.vivienneclore.com/artist-details/sandi-toksvig/ |title=Artist Management |publisher=Vivienne Clore |date= |accessdate=16 March 2012}} ''[[The Saturday Starship]]'', ''[[Motormouth]]'', ''[[Gilbert the Alien|Gilbert's Fridge]]'', and on factual programmes such as ''Island Race'' and ''The Talking Show'', produced by [[Open Media]] for [[Channel 4]]. In October 2012, in the wake of allegations about the behaviour of [[Jimmy Savile#Allegations of sexual abuse|Jimmy Savile]], and claims that during the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s, there was a culture within the BBC which [[Criticism of the BBC#Jimmy Savile sexual abuse allegations|tolerated sexual harassment]], she says she was groped by a "famous individual" on air in the 1980s.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19861688 |title=Sandi Toksvig claims she was groped while broadcasting |date=7 October 2012 |work=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=9 October 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/07/sandi-toksvig-i-was-groped-on-air |title=Sandi Toksvig: 'I was groped on air in the 1980s' |date=7 October 2012 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=9 October 2012 }} Toksvig said the allegations of inappropriate behaviour at the BBC "did not surprise me at all". ===Comedy=== In the comedy circuit, Toksvig performed at the first night of the [[The Comedy Store, London|Comedy Store]] in [[London]], and was once part of [[The Comedy Store Players|their Players]], an [[improvisational comedy]] team.[http://www.comedystoreplayers.com/history.html Comedy Store Players Official Site – History] -retrieved on 16 May 2008 In television, she appeared as a panellist in comedy shows such as ''[[Call My Bluff (UK game show)|Call My Bluff]]'' (a regular as a team captain), ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (UK TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[QI]]'', and ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', where she appeared on the very first episode in 1990.[http://www.tv.com/have-i-got-news-for-you/show/2627/episode_listings.html?season=1&tag=nav_bar;1 Have I Got News For You episode guide] at TV.com — retrieved on 16 May 2008 She was also the host of ''[[What the Dickens]]'', a [[Sky Arts]] [[quiz show]]. On radio, she is a familiar voice for BBC Radio 4 listeners, having appeared on ''[[I'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue]]'', [[The Unbelievable Truth (radio show)|''The Unbelievable Truth'']], and as the chair of ''[[The News Quiz]]'', where she replaced [[Simon Hoggart]] in September 2006, but left in June 2015 in order to enter politics to champion women's rights. Her final show was first broadcast on 26 June. She presented Radio 4's travel programme ''Excess Baggage'' until it was axed in 2012. {{cite news|url=http://www.wanderlust.co.uk/magazine/news/bbc-radio-4s-excess-baggage-decommissioned|first=|last=|title=Radio 4's Excess Baggage to be axed|work=Wanderlust|date=2012-03-20|accessdate=2016-01-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202101608/http://www.wanderlust.co.uk/magazine/news/bbc-radio-4s-excess-baggage-decommissioned|archivedate=2 February 2016|df=dmy-all}} ===Drama and factual=== In 1993, Toksvig wrote a musical, ''Big Night Out at the Little Sands Picture Palace'', for [[Nottingham Playhouse]], co-starring with [[Anita Dobson]] and [[Una Stubbs]]. In 2002, it was re-written, with [[Dilly Keane]], for the [[Watford#Watford Palace Theatre|Watford Palace Theatre]], in which they appeared with [[Bonnie Langford]].[http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821025025538 Review of ''Big Night Out'' in What's On Stage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616055325/http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821025025538 |date=16 June 2011 }}; retrieved 23 February 2009. Toksvig and Elly Brewer wrote a Shakespeare deconstruction, ''The Pocket Dream'', which Toksvig performed at the [[Nottingham Playhouse]] and which transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] for a short run. The pair also wrote the 1992 TV series ''[[The Big One (TV series)|The Big One]]'', in which she also starred. She has appeared in a number of stage plays, including ''[[Androcles and the Lion (play)|Androcles and the Lion]]'', ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'', and ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]''. In 1996, she narrated the ''Dragons!'' interactive CD-ROM published by Oxford University Press and developed by Inner Workings, along with [[Harry Enfield]].{{cite web | title = Television graphics around the world | url = http://www.meldrum.co.uk/mhp/testcard/around_world.html | website = meldrum.co.uk | date = 29 March 2000 | access-date = 26 April 2013 }} The software was primarily aimed at children and featured songs and poems about dragons. She also narrated the ''Winnie the Witch'' CD-ROM. She appeared in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' audio drama ''[[Red (Doctor Who audio)|Red]]'' by [[Big Finish Productions]], released in August 2006. In December 2006, she hosted and sang at the [[London Gay Men's Chorus]] sold-out Christmas show, ''Make the Yuletide Gay'', at the [[Barbican Arts Centre|Barbican Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.barbican.org.uk/music/event-detail.asp?ID=4705|first=|last=|title=Music Event Detail|work=|date=|accessdate=2016-01-26}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Over Christmas and New Year 2007/2008, she narrated the [[pantomime]] ''Cinderella'' at the [[Old Vic Theatre]]. In October 2011, she narrated the new musical ''[[Soho Cinders]]'' at the [[Queen's Theatre]], London. In 2011 she hosted a second season of [[BBC Two]]'s ''Antiques Master''. Toksvig wrote a play entitled ''[[Bully Boy]]'' which focused on [[post-traumatic stress]] among British servicemen. The play premièred at the [[University of Southampton#Highfield Campus|Nuffield Theatre]] in Southampton in May 2011, and starred [[Anthony Andrews]].{{cite web|title=Sandi Toksvig on Bully Boy|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/brighton-theatre/news/05-2011/sandi-toksvig-on-bully-boy_8993.html|website=WhatsOnStage|accessdate=17 March 2017}} The play then launched the debut season of [[The Other Palace|St James Theatre]] in September 2012, the first new West End theatre to open in 30 years.{{cite web|title=St James Theatre in London's West End opens|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-19636447|website=BBC News|accessdate=17 March 2017}} In the 2013 Christmas Special of BBC's ''[[Call the Midwife]]'', Toksvig made a cameo appearance as grumpy ward nurse Sister Gibbs.{{cite news | last = O'Donovan | first = Gerard |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/10531223/Call-the-Midwife-Christmas-special-review.html |title=''Call the Midwife'', Christmas special, review |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=25 December 2013 |accessdate=31 December 2013}}{{cite news | last = Walker-Arnott | first = Ellie |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-12-04/call-the-midwife-christmas-special---first-look-preview |title=''Call the Midwife'' Christmas special — first look preview |work=[[Radio Times]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=31 December 2013 }} Toksvig was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2014 New Year Honours]] for services to broadcasting.{{London Gazette|issue=60728 |supp=y|page=14|date=31 December 2013}} On 28 April 2015, it was announced that Toksvig would leave BBC Radio 4's ''The News Quiz'' in June at the end of the 28th series, which was scheduled to begin on 15 May of that year. She said: "I have decided it is time to move on and, of course, I feel sad but I think it's the right moment. The show is in great shape and, like a good house guest, you should always depart when people still wish you'd stay a bit longer." The BBC said Toksvig had made the "difficult decision" to leave in order "to embark on a new and exciting stage of her career".{{cite news |title= Sandi Toksvig steps down from Radio 4's ''News Quiz'' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-32495153 |author= |date= 28 April 2015 |work=[[BBC News Online]] | publisher = BBC |accessdate=12 May 2015}} On 30 April 2015, Toksvig announced that her decision to quit ''The News Quiz'' had been made in order to allow her to help set up a new political party named the [[Women's Equality Party]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/apr/30/sandi-toksvig-quit-radio-4-news-quiz-set-up-womens-rights-political-party |title=Sandi Toksvig reveals she quit Radio 4 to set up women's rights political party |last1=Topping |first1=Alexandra |date=30 April 2015 |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=30 April 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/bbc/11574333/Sandi-Toksvig-quit-The-News-Quiz-for-Womens-Equality-Party.html|title=Sandi Toksvig quit ''The News Quiz'' for Women's Equality Party |first=Hannah |last=Furness |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=30 April 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2015 }} In November 2015, Toksvig was a guest of [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Desert Island Discs]]''. Her choices included [[Joe Nichols]] ("[[What's a Guy Gotta Do]]"), [[Gustav Winckler]], [[The Weather Girls]], [[Barbra Streisand]], and [[Bonnie Langford]]. Her book choice was ''[[The Ashley Book of Knots]]'', and her luxury item was an endless supply of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06qg1ls |title=BBC Radio 4 – Desert Island Discs, Sandi Toksvig |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=29 November 2015|accessdate=4 December 2015}} Her most recent play [[Silver Lining (Play)|''Silver Lining'']] opened at the Rose Theatre Kingston on 11 February 2017, before touring to Portsmouth, Oxford, Cambridge, Ipswich, Keswick, York, and Salford. It's about five elderly ladies and a young carer in a retirement home which is about to be flooded by a storm. It stars [[Rachel Davies]], [[Keziah Joseph]], Maggie McCarthy, [[Joanna Monro]], [[Sheila Reid]], and [[Amanda Walker]]. Toksvig's son, [[Theo Toksvig-Stewart]], made his professional stage debut in the play.{{cite web|title=Sandy Toksvig's Silver Lining|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/first-look-sandi-toksvig-silver-lining_42841.html|website=WhatsOnStage|accessdate=17 March 2017}} ===Writing=== She has written more than twenty fiction and non-fiction books for children and adults, starting in 1994 with ''Tales from the Norse's Mouth'', a fiction tale for children. In 1995, she sailed around the coast of Britain with [[John McCarthy (journalist)|John McCarthy]], who had been held hostage in [[Beirut]]. In 2003, she published ''Gladys Reunited: A Personal American Journey'', about her travels in the USA retracing her childhood. She writes regular columns for ''[[Good Housekeeping]]'', the ''[[Sunday Telegraph]]'' and ''[[The Lady (magazine)|The Lady]]''. In October 2008, she published ''Girls Are Best'', a [[women's history|history book for girls]].{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/sandi-toksvig-interview-the-history-woman-1-1148798|title=Sandi Toksvig interview: The history woman|work = The Scotsman|date=27 November 2008|accessdate=26 January 2016}} In 2009, her collected columns for ''The Sunday Telegraph'' were published in book form as ''The Chain of Curiosity''. In 2012, she published her latest book, ''Valentine Grey'', a historical novel set in the [[Boer War]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/fictionreviews/9558294/Valentine-Grey-by-Sandi-Toksvig-review.html|first=Lucy|last=Beresford|title=Valentine Grey by Sandi Toksvig: review |work = The Telegraph |date=27 September 2012 |accessdate=26 January 2016}} ===Television presenter=== In 2012–13 Toksvig presented ''[[1001 Things You Should Know]]'' for [[Channel 4]] daytime. Toksvig began presenting the revival edition of the daytime game show ''[[Fifteen-to-One]]'' in April 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2014-04-02/fifteen-to-one-returns-behind-the-scenes-with-sandi-toksvig|title=Fifteen to One returnos: behind the scenes with Sandi Toksvig|first=Emma|last=Daly|work=Radio Times|date=2 April 2014|accessdate=5 August 2015}} It is an hour long instead of the original half-hour edition presented by [[William G. Stewart]]. After two series had been broadcast, in June 2015, Channel 4 announced that a further three would be made, hosted by Toksvig.{{cite web|url=http://newsonnews.com/story/080615-620|title=Channel 4 Commits to Sandi Toksvig's Fifteen to One|website=News on News|date=8 June 2015|accessdate=5 August 2015}} Toksvig took over from [[Stephen Fry]] as host of ''[[QI]]''; she hosted the first episode of the show's series "N", which was broadcast on 21 October 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/10/21/qi-sandi-toksvig-triumphs-in-her-first-appearance-as-host|title=QI Sandi Toksvig triumphs in her first appearance as host|website=The Telegraph|date=21 October 2016|accessdate=21 October 2016}} In September 2018, Toksvig reported that she was only paid 40% of what Fry, her predecessor, had received. Toksvig had earlier told the [[Radio Times]] it would be “absurd” if she did not receive the same salary as Fry for chairing QI.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/sep/08/sandi-toksvig-reveals-60-qi-pay-gap-from-stephen-fry|title=Sandi Toksvig sparks new gender pay row over QI fee|last=Thorpe|first=Vanessa|last2=Graham-Harrison|first2=Emma|date=2018-09-08|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-09-08}} On 16 March 2017 she was announced as the new co-presenter of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]'' on [[Channel 4]] alongside [[Noel Fielding]]. They replaced the previous hosts [[Sue Perkins]] and [[Mel Giedroyc]]. ==Politics and activism== Toksvig was part of [[Red Wedge]]'s comedy tour in the 1980s which supported the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] Party. She was later a high-profile political activist supporting the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]].{{cite web|url=http://liberalengland.blogspot.co.uk/2013/02/time-for-sandi-toksvig-to-give-up-news.html | title = Liberal England: Time for Sandi Toksvig to give up The News Quiz | website = liberalengland.blogspot.co.uk | publisher = Liberal England (blog) | accessdate=13 April 2015}}{{cite news | title = Screen stars join election race | work = [[BBC news]] | publisher = BBC | date = 25 May 2004 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3745121.stm | accessdate = 16 October 2008 | quote = "The celebrity bug has bitten the other major parties with the Lib Dems claiming the support of [...] broadcaster Sandi Toksvig." }} She both introduced frontbencher [[Menzies Campbell]] at the party's 2004 conference and was named as a possible parliamentary candidate.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In 2003 she stood as a candidate in the election for the [[Chancellor]]ship of the [[University of Oxford]], supporting a campaign against [[Top-up fees|student fees]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/2793657.stm | title= Toksvig enters chancellor race |work=[[BBC News]] | publisher = BBC | date=24 February 2003|accessdate=16 March 2012}} She was defeated in the first round of voting, achieving 1,179 first-place votes out of about 8,000 cast.{{cite news | last = Curtis | first = Polly | title = Patten wins Oxford prize | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/news/story/0,9830,915896,00.html?=rss | date = 17 March 2003 | work = [[The Guardian]] | accessdate = 24 May 2008| location = London, UK }} The election was won by [[Chris Patten]]. In 2011, some MPs urged [[Ofcom]] to investigate an "obscene joke" after Toksvig said on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[The News Quiz]]'' that the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] had "put the 'N' into cuts" to child benefit.{{cite news | last = Blake | first = Heidi | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/8557822/BBC-in-decency-row-over-obscene-joke-by-Sandi-Toksvig.html | title = BBC in decency row over obscene joke by Sandi Toksvig | work = Daily Telegraph |accessdate=13 April 2015}} In 2012, she said in an interview that "I don't think there's a party that represents anything I believe in".{{cite news | last = Saner | first = Emine | title = Sandi Toksvig: 'I don't understand boredom' | work = The Guardian | date = 26 August 2012 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/aug/26/sandi-toksvig-interview | accessdate = 26 August 2012 }} Toksvig supports the charity and pressure group [[Liberty (pressure group)|Liberty]], hosting its 2012 awards ceremony.{{cite web | title = Liberty honours inspirational human rights leaders | url = http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/media/press/2012/liberty-honours-inspirational-human-rights-leaders-in-an.php | website = liberty-human-rights.org.uk | date = 20 November 2012 | access-date = 26 April 2013 }} Toksvig attracted further criticism in 2015 for a joke on the subject of [[UK Independence Party|UKIP]] leader [[Nigel Farage]] having lost a testicle to cancer.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2015/05/sandi-toksvig-makes-hitler-jibe-about-nigel-farage/|title=Sandi Toksvig makes Hitler jibe about Nigel Farage - Coffee House|date=26 May 2015|work=The Spectator}} She was appointed president of the [[Women of the Year Lunch]].{{cite web | title= The President | url= http://www.womenoftheyear.co.uk/the-board-council/the-presidents-message/ | author= | website= Women of the Year | accessdate= 7 May 2015 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150125075401/http://www.womenoftheyear.co.uk/the-board-council/the-presidents-message/ | archivedate= 25 January 2015 | df= dmy-all }} ===Women's Equality Party=== In April 2015, Toksvig chaired the first, informal, conference of a new political party, the [[Women's Equality Party]],{{cite news | last = Cocozza | first = Paula | title = Women's Equality party founders: 'It needed doing. So we said, "Let's do it"' | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/28/womens-equality-party-founders-it-needed-doing-so-we-said-lets-do-it-sandi-toksvig | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 28 August 2015 | accessdate = 21 September 2015 }}{{cite news | url = https://www.standard.co.uk/news/londoners-diary/londoners-diary-womens-party-is-ready-to-be-a-player-10189809.html | title = Londoner's Diary: Women's party is ready to be a player | work = [[London Evening Standard]] | date = 20 April 2015 | accessdate = 23 April 2015}} and she subsequently left her job as presenter of ''The News Quiz'' to become co-founder of the party. She later explained that she had decided that it was "not too late to fight the good fight, after all".{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/25/sandi-toksvig-trolls-womens-equality-party-bbc-abuse | title = Sandi Toksvig: trolls are already out over plans to form Women's Equality party | work = [[The Guardian]] | first = Jessica | last = Elgot | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 25 May 2015 | accessdate = 27 May 2015 }} In September the same year she announced the dates for a comedy tour to raise funds for the party.{{cite news | last = Duffy | first = Nick | title = Sandi Toksvig launches comedy tour to raise funds for new political party | url = https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2015/09/29/sandi-toksvig-launches-comedy-tour-to-raise-funds-for-new-political-party/ | work = [[PinkNews]] | publisher = | date = 29 September 2015 | access-date = 29 September 2015 }}{{cite news | last = Nixey | first = Catherine | title = Sandi Toksvig on swapping The News Quiz for the Women's Equality Party | url = http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/article4570067.ece | work = [[The Times]] | publisher = [[News UK]] | subscription = yes | date = 29 September 2015 | access-date = 29 September 2015 }} The party's full set of policies were launched at [[Conway Hall]], 20 October 2015.{{cite web | title = Women's Equality Party announces first policies and campaigns | url = http://www.womensequality.org.uk/policy_launch_announcement | publisher = [[Women's Equality Party]] | date = 20 October 2015 | accessdate = 21 October 2015 }}{{cite news | last = Minter | first = Harriet | title = The Women's Equality Party launch is not a moment too soon | url = https://www.theguardian.com/women-in-leadership/2015/oct/21/the-womens-equality-party-launch-is-not-a-moment-too-soon | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 21 October 2015 | accessdate = 21 October 2015 }} ==Personal life== As an eleven-year-old, Toksvig was present with her father, a leading Danish foreign affairs journalist, at [[NASA]] [[Christopher C. Kraft Jr. Mission Control Center|Mission Control Center]] in Houston, Texas during the [[Apollo 11|first moon landing]].QI XL. Series N;10. Nature/Nurture, BBC. UK Broadcast 30 Dec 2016Kerr, Alison (29 November 2008). "Sandi Toksvig interview: The history woman". ''[[The Scotsman]]''. Retrieved 4 Jan 2017 In an appearance on BBC 1 show ''[[The TV That Made Me]]'', she stated she held the hand of [[Neil Armstrong]]'s nervous secretary to calm the woman down during the final moments. She also revealed she had a lifetime fear of children's television puppet [[Basil Brush]], although, ironically, she had written a 2002 episode of ''[[The Basil Brush Show]]'' entitled "Molly Christmas". {{Quote box |quote=I wouldn’t care if they came from Tesco. I don’t care about the blood thing. They call me Mummy and I earned it. We love each other. You can’t do better than that. Lots of families don’t.|source=Toksvig commenting on her children in ''[[The Times]]''{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article1169426.ece | archiveurl = |last=Kerr|first=Alison}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/feb/20/jesse-toksvig-stewart-my-two-mums-were-trailblazers|title=Jesse Toksvig-Stewart: My two mums were |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article6942389.ece|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615084301/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article6942389.ece|archivedate=15 Lloyd-Pack]].{{cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=DgGjrBYSdR2j54Ol8PP2wg&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=1 December 2013|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}}{{cite Wandsworth Guardian |date=31 December 2013 |accessdate=31 December 2013 | location = London, UK}} with psychotherapist Debbie Toksvig, whom she joined in a [[civil partnership in the United The '''Special Field Force''' (SFF) is a [[Namibia]]n [[Namibian Police Force|Police Force]] [[paramilitary]] [[police]] unit created in 1995 by the late commissioner [[Danger Ashipala|Ruben "Danger" Ashipala]] as an auxiliary aggressive unit to complement the [[Special Reserve Force]] (SRF). It encompasses border guards, [[Very Important Person|VIP]] Protection Unit and Installation unit. Approximately half of the Namibian Police's (NAMPOL) overall complement is assigned to the SFF which is made up primarily of combatants from the former [[People's Liberation Army of Namibia]] (PLAN) and [[South West African Territorial Force]] (SWATF).<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61584.htm | title = Country Reports on Human Rights Practices - 2005 | publisher = U.S. Department of State | accessdate = 2008-11-08 }}</ref>
Among the population the Special Field Force is seen as the less educated and more brutal wing of the Namibian Police. They have been implicated in the intimidation, assault, torture and also murder of civilians in the [[Caprivi conflict|secessionist uprisings]] in Namibia's [[Caprivi Strip]] in 1998 and 1999.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://namibweb.com/article2.htm | title = CIVIL SUPREMACY OF THE MILITARY IN NAMIBIA: A RETROSPECTIVE CASE STUDY | publisher = NamibWeb | accessdate = 2008-11-08 }}</ref>
Also later, under normal and calm political conditions, human rights groups accused the Special Field Force of several atrocities, e.g.: * 2002 in May officers of the Special Field Force detained and assaulted Namibian men [[LGBT rights in Namibia|suspected of being gay]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,AMNESTY,,NAM,456d621e2,3cf4bc0334,0.html | title = Amnesty International Report 2002 | publisher = Amnesty International | accessdate = 2008-11-08 }}</ref> * 2003 in October nine minors were arrested on suspicion of housebreaking. Several police officers wearing SFF uniforms, as well as plain-clothes detectives, reportedly beat and tortured them with whips and electric shocks.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://asiapacific.amnesty.org/report2003/nam-summary-eng | title = Amnesty International Report 2003 | publisher = Amnesty International | accessdate = 2008-11-08 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> * 2006, on February 17, two off duty members of the [[Okahao]] Police's Special Field Force, constables Amadhila and Kamanya, allegedly led a mob in the assault of two women accused of witchcraft. * 2006, March 2, members of the SFF police unit and the [[Military of Namibia|Namibian Defence Force]] (NDF), who were sent to [[Mariental, Namibia|Mariental]] to maintain law and order after a flood, randomly assaulted residents of the town.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78749.htm | title = Country Reports on Human Rights Practices - 2006 | publisher = U.S. Department of State | accessdate = 2008-11-08 }}</ref> * 2007, on June 5, SFF executed an unprovoked attack on demonstrating war veterans.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.iol.co.za/news/africa/unprovoked-police-attack-on-war-vets-1.356169 | title = “Unprovoked Police Attack” On War Vets | date = 5 June 2007 | publisher = The Institute for Security Studies, South Africa (via iol.com) }}</ref>

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = State Hydraulic Works |nativename = Devlet Su İşleri (DSİ) |logo = Logo - Türkisches Amt für Wasserwirtschaft.svg |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |headquarters = [[Ankara]] |formed = 1954 |preceding = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Turkey]] |employees = 20.184 |budget = 8.873.363.000 TL |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |chief1_name = Director-General |chief1_position = Murat Acu |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = [[Ministry of Forest and Water Management (Turkey)|Ministry of Forest and Water Management]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{URL|http://www.dsi.gov.tr/}} |footnotes = }}
The '''State Hydraulic Works''' ({{lang-tr|Devlet Su İşleri}}) is a [[state agency]] organized under the [[Ministry of Environment and Forestry (Turkey)|Ministry of Environment and Forestry]] of [[Turkey]]<ref>[http://www.dsi.gov.tr/kurumsal/yonetim.htm State Hydraulic Works Organization] {{tr icon}}</ref> responsible for the utilization of all the country's water resources. The institution's four major functions are energy, agriculture, services and environment.
==History== Development of water resources in Turkey began with the establishment of the "General Directorate of Public Works" ({{lang-ota|Umur-u Nafia Müdüriyet-i Umumiyesi}}) by the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Government]] in 1914. The institution started to undertake continuous and systematical studies on [[irrigation]], [[water reclamation|reclamation]], [[flood control]], navigation, water storage and distribution.
in 1925, soon after the foundation of the Turkish Republic, regional offices were opened in [[Adana]], [[Ankara]], [[Bursa, Turkey|Bursa]], [[Edirne]] and [[Izmir]] under the "Waters Directorate". Due to insufficient financial resources and field observations data available, water projects could not be expedited as planned. Severe drought, occurred in 1929, led to the establishment of the more comprehensive institution of "Waters General Directorate". In 1939, it was reorganized in "Water Works General Directorate". The agency conducted studies on feasibility, planning, gauging and water level recording.
Finally in 1954, the institution was named "General Directorate of State Hydraulic Works" and assigned to the Ministry of Public Works.<ref>[http://www.dsi.gov.tr/english/about/tarihcee.htm DSI History]</ref> State Hydraulic Works was reassigned later to the Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources. Since not a long time, the agency reports to the minister of environment and forestry.
==Organization== The State Hydraulic Works is organized in three levels: The management, the department offices and the regional offices. While the first two levels are located in [[Ankara]], the 25 regional offices are dispersed throughout Turkey.
Major functions of the regional offices are primarily collection of data in the field of mapping, conducting hydrometric measurements, surveying agricultural economy, land classification, drainage, [[groundwater]] and geology, and secondly to evaluate them for the planning, construction and operation of water structures.<ref>[http://www.dsi.gov.tr/english/about/orge.htm DSI Organization]</ref>
==Projects== Since its establishment in 1954, State Hydraulic Works has made investments in the sector of energy for US$30.0 billion, agriculture for US$39.0 billion and services for US$12.0 billion, totaling up to US$81.0 billion.
===Energy=== Of the 135 [[hydroelectric power plant]]s (HEPP) in Turkey, State Hydraulic Works operates 53, which have a total installed capacity of 10,215 [[megawatt|MW]] (29% of the country's total electric power capacity) and generated in 2003 electricity of 35,329 [[GWh]] (25.1% of the total).
State Hydraulic Works has currently 24 HEPPs throughout the country under construction with a total installed capacity of 2,722 MW and annual generation of 8,920 GWh.<ref>[http://www.dsi.gov.tr/english/service/enerjie.htm State Hydraulic Works Energy]</ref>
===Agriculture=== [[Image:Distribution canals-GAP.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Distribution canals]] Turkey has a total of 280,000 square kilometres of agricultural area, of which 85,000 km² is economically irrigable and 49,000 km² is currently being irrigated.<ref name=Darama>{{cite web |url=http://www.unido.org/file-storage/download/?file_id=84741 |title=Water Issues and the Role of State Hydraulic Works in Water Resources Development in Turkey|author=Yakup Darama}}</ref> As of 2005, an area of 28,000 km² is equipped with facilities of State Hydraulic Works's irrigation projects, making 10% of the total agricultural area and 57% of the irrigated area in Turkey.<ref name=Agriculture>{{cite web|url=http://www.dsi.gov.tr/english/service/tarime.htm|title=DSI Agriculture}}</ref>
====Southeastern Anatolia Project (GAP)==== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:GAP Region.jpg|thumb|right|250px]] --> The [[Southeastern Anatolia Project]] ({{lang-tr|Güneydoğu Anadolu Projesi}} or GAP), a very important integrated project for the economic and social development of the [[Southeastern Anatolia Region, Turkey|Southeastern Anatolia Region]], includes active farming with extensive irrigation systems and electricity generation. The project area covers the lower parts of the [[Euphrates]] and [[Tigris]] rivers in the 9 provinces of the region ([[Gaziantep Province|Gaziantep]], [[Adıyaman Province|Adıyaman]], [[Kilis Province|Kilis]], [[Şanlıurfa Province|Şanlıurfa]], [[Diyarbakır Province|Diyarbakır]], [[Mardin Province|Mardin]], [[Siirt Province|Siirt]], [[Batman Province|Batman]], and [[Şırnak Province|Şırnak]]), where a total of 6.5 million people live as of the 2000 census.
The project is one of the biggest investments of the last century undertaken by State Hydraulic Works and contains 13 sub-projects, 7 of which are in the Euphrates Basin and 6 of which are in the Tigris Basin. Within the scope of these 13 projects, 27,000 GWh hydroelectric energy will be produced annually with 7.5 GW installed capacity and 18,200 km² of land will be irrigated with the construction of 22 dams and 19 HEPPs.<ref name=Agriculture />
[[Image:Ataturk dam 1-GAP.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Atatürk Dam]] The [[Atatürk Dam]], the largest in Turkey and among the [[List of largest dams|world's largest dams]], is the centerpiece of the project.
===Services=== State Hydraulic Works is responsible by law for the supply of domestic and industrial water to settlements having population of more than 100,000. As of the 2000 census, there are 55 cities and towns in Turkey with populations over 100,000. State Hydraulic Works supply water to 26 million people<ref name=Darama /> in 45 cities at different regions.
As of the beginning of 2005, State Hydraulic Works supplied annually a total of around 2.5 km³ domestic water complying with drinking water standards. This figure will reach 5.3 km³ with completion of the projects which are under construction, or at the final design and planning stages. Water supply projects developed by State Hydraulic Works meet one third of the requirements for domestic and industrial water consumption.<ref>[http://www.dsi.gov.tr/english/service/icmekulsue.htm DSI Domestic water]</ref>
===Environment=== The protection of nature and wildlife is of great importance for State Hydraulic Works. It conducts activities on development of sustainable water resources, both independently and in collaboration with other related governmental and non-governmental organizations. State Hydraulic Works also provides financial and technical support to protect archaeological and historical sites for the next generations.
One of the basic duties and responsibilities of State Hydraulic Works is building and operating protective structures against floods. It takes the necessary precautions and warns the relevant organizations in the event of flood emergencies.
State Hydraulic Works conducts afforestation work and establishes recreation areas and facilities aiming at prevention of erosion, decreasing the sediment amount deposited in dams through rivers, restoring the environment of dam basins and their catchments. Tree planted areas also serve as picnic areas and public promenades.
State Hydraulic Works needs to obtain land properties (real estates) for its development projects of water and land resources. Up to now, around 5,200 km² of private land was expropriated. 70,000 families and 350,000 people were relocated by dam projects. It is estimated that 50,000 families and 250,000 people more will be affected in the future.<ref>[http://www.dsi.gov.tr/english/service/cevree.htm DSI Environment]</ref>
==Notable executives== * [[Süleyman Demirel]], former [[List of Prime Ministers of Turkey|prime minister]] and the [[List of Presidents of Turkey|9th president of Turkey]]. Served as director general of DSI between 1955-1960.<ref>[http://www.allaboutturkey.com/demirel.htm All About Turkey]</ref> * [[Veysel Eroğlu]], current minister of environment and forestry. Served as State Hydraulic Works's director general from 2003 to 2007.<ref>[http://www.veyseleroglu.gen.tr/index.php?dil=1&kat=33 Veysel Eroğlu's personal website]</ref>
